A couple points to consider: Flexibility is not actually a good feature in a razor blade if you want it to stay sharp. A straight razor is an intensely delicate instrument, with a good one being really hard and brittle, rather than flexible like a spring. These will shatter very easily, but won't bend, and will have minimal edge rolling occurring during normal use, and their design specializes in minimizing edge roll by having a curve along the width of the blade, which stiffens things considerably. Stropping helped further with edge retention, which is why a good barber regularly stropped, but didn't sharpen his razor nearly as often. Cartridge razors can't be stropped, and are designed to flex a great deal, and are usually stainless (or nearly so), none of which are helpful if you want either a sharp edge in the first place, or to maintain an edge. Note, those soft spots you mention are more of a drawback/feature of stainless steel, if hard enough carbon steel was used, it would be less of an issue, as this has harder 'soft' spots.

I suspect the sheer thinness of disposable blades is also an issue here, with the blades being insufficient to the task, because a thinner blade is cheaper/easier to fit 12 of them in one cartridge.

Another factor is that all blades are a compromise between flexibility and hardness. The potential hardness of steel depends mostly on the carbon content. However, high carbon steel needs to not only be hardened, but also tempered. Tempering is a controlled softening of the steel to avoid chipping and breaking.

A multi-blade razor has a set of tiny hair thin blades that must be hard enough to hold an edge but flexible enough that they don’t snap the first time you press them to your face. It’s a compromise that leans towards flexibility.

If you have a thick, blocky blade like a mortising chisel you can harden the cutting edge and give it a gradual hard to soft temper along its length. This is called a step temper. With a tiny razor blade it’s all done in bulk in an oven, so the back of the blade is just as hard/flexible as the edge. A compromise.

And so we replace our blades.

Wrought iron is similar but never fully melts. Impurities fall out and burn away as the metal is repeatedly re-shaped, i.e. worked or wrought.
